generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, has been the subject of intense research for decades. However, the structure of ice II with a guest molecule dissolved in it has not been resolved. Here, we report the structure of ice II with neon dissolved in it at 480 MPa and 260 K. The guest Ne atoms occupy the centers of D2O channels and have substantial freedom of movement owing to the lack of direct bonding between guest molecules and host lattices. The structure is thermodynamically stable at 480 MPa and 260 K. This work provides a unique insight into the structure of ice II and the properties of the guest–host system. It also provides a reference for the study of the structure of ice II at other pressures and temperatures. This work is expected to be useful for the development of new materials and the understanding of the properties of the guest–host system.

Quantum mechanics is a highly successful theory, but its foundations are unclear. This paper provides a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The approach is inspired by the work of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The approach provides a way to understand the structure of quantum mechanics that is independent of any particular mathematical formalism.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause disease in a wide range of animals, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, but a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results provide insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. They also suggest that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that contribute to their pathogenicity. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by interfering with the nuclear import of ISGs. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will make it more difficult to produce enough food for the world’s growing population. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries as the Earth’s mean temperature increases. This increase in variability will make it more difficult to produce enough food, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. We also show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases in all major maize-exporting countries under 2 °C of global warming and in all countries under 4 °C of global warming. Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, these species differed in diet composition, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our approach provides a powerful tool for quantifying diet in large herbivores, and for understanding the role of niche partitioning in structuring herbivore assemblages. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off or furloughed workers and are closing. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible signs of the pollution of the ocean. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of the millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic by a combination of processes, such as nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study highlights the importance of size-selective sinks in the fate of floating plastic debris and the need for a better understanding of the global distribution of the different size fractions of floating plastic debris. This will be crucial to assess the magnitude of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the universe. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is one of the most important adaptations that can be made to increase reproductive output. Here, we show that a variety of mechanisms to increase maternal energy availability can increase reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a fundamental finding that will help us understand the evolution of reproduction in mammals and other species. It also has implications for the evolution of domestication and allonursing in humans. View Full-Text

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a key player in the neurotoxic process. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

It is the primary regulator of the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is the only cell type in the blood vessels that is in direct contact with the blood. The endothelium is responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, inflammation, and the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor the pandemic and inform public health policy. However, the data are often not available in a form that is useful for policy makers, epidemiologists, and researchers. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides a common interface to a wide range of data sources, including public health surveillance data, deidentified medical claims data, and online survey data. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the data can be used to monitor the pandemic and to inform public health policy. The API is available for use by the public.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in potassium channels. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood, but the gut microbiome is thought to be influenced by the host and the host's diet. The gut microbiome is also thought to be influenced by the host's lifestyle, such as the host's exercise regimen and the host's occupation. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are part of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used as therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for brain energy metabolism. We found that high-anxious animals are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this low probability to become dominant is associated with reduced brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is highly desired for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design approach, which is a powerful tool in the field of music composition. The inverse design approach is used to determine the material properties of the constituent materials and the optimal geometric patterns of the composite structures. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which is a powerful technique in the field of additive manufacturing. The structures are then tested to verify the desired responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to the design and manufacture of multifunctional architectures with complex responses. The strategy can also be applied to other fields, such as music composition and architecture design.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the IGF2BP1 protein is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in fetal tissues and is down-regulated in adult tissues. We also show that IGF2BP1 can affect the timing of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a target for therapeutic intervention in hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. We found that this resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis. This mechanism of resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, and we show that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings provide a potential therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used class of antihypertensive drugs, the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers, are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Here, we show that these drugs act on the Ca2+ signaling machinery to promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is often unsuccessful. Here, we present a computational approach to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. We used a computational model to predict the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We then tested the predicted best candidates in vitro and in vivo. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our approach can be used to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics and to reduce the risk of failure in the drug development process. This article is protected by copyright. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be very large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, and that is easier to train and apply. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. We show that the proposed network architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The network architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We believe that the proposed network architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The study of past climate and lake-level variability is critical for understanding the evolution of the Earth system and the impact of climate change on the environment and human society. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. We also observe that periods of high lake level are observed during times of high eccentricity. These results provide a unique insight into the evolution of the climate system and the impact of climate change on the environment and human society. (Less)

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. In particular, the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime phase-delay the circadian clock, acutely suppress melatonin, and reduce the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Ytterby meteorite, which fell in Sweden in 1739, is the only known source of the element osmium (Os). Os is used in the manufacture of magnetic materials, which are important in the electronics industry. The Ytterby meteorite is the only source of Os in the world, and the supply of this element is limited. The YDB is a unique opportunity to study the origin of Os in the Earth’s crust.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult organism is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is driven by the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and that the evolution of their diet is a key driver of beetle diversification.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE). We find that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, we find that the size of the population may actually have a negative effect on CCE. Our findings have important implications for the study of the evolution of technology and the development of technologies in the real world.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease in APOE4 carriers. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may contribute to Alzheimer’s disease through its effect on the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the size of a small country. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is the only part of the Earth that is not in contact with the surface. It is a mystery why the inner core is solid, and how it formed. We show that the inner core formed by a two-step process. First, the inner core started forming when molten iron cooled below the melting point. Second, the molten iron cooled below the bcc to hcp phase transformation temperature. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are well known, the brain mechanisms that contribute to the abuse of this drug are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most fundamental of its cognitive functions. Here, we show that deep learning models of language processing in the human brain are predictive of brain activity in response to spoken language, generalize across datasets, and predict how language is processed in the brain even when we do not know what the language is. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in language comprehension, and they suggest that the brain’s language machinery is tuned to the structure of language in a way that is similar across languages.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, which is well-conditioned. We introduce a new class of neural networks that are stable and prove that they are the only stable networks that can be computed by an algorithm. This is a major step toward understanding the limits of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of risk perception. One of the most influential studies in this field is a classic experiment published in 1974. It is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the study’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time and are discussed here. They led to the study’s conclusion being supported, while still undermining its methodology. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and its history is intertwined with the study of leprosy bacilli. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a new species of leprosy bacillus, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We also compared the genome of this new species with that of the other leprosy bacillus, which is associated with the more severe form of the disease, known as leprosy. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli have diverged little since their separation from their MRCA, and therefore, despite their ancient separation, they are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main quantities that are used to quantify the state of a physical system. However, they are not the same. In fact, they are related by a nonlocal quantity, the von Neumann entropy. In this work, we study the evolution of the von Neumann entropy in a generic isolated quantum system. We show that the entanglement dynamics is completely determined by the initial state and the dynamics of the system. This result is a major step toward the understanding of the evolution of the von Neumann entropy in isolated systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a vaccine candidate that can be produced in large quantities and is highly protective against COVID-19.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, which is the first of its kind. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to explain the spread of the disease in the Americas. It also provides a framework for studying the history of other diseases spread by human ectoparasites.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research on animal cognition. However, it is not the only way to measure brain complexity. We show that the number of neurons is a more accurate measure of brain complexity and that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. These shifts are associated with the evolution of higher cognitive abilities in birds and mammals.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation, but the results have been mixed. We have shown that TRAP1 is required for the survival of cells that have acquired oncogenic mutations, and that it is necessary for the invasiveness of cells that have lost the ability to die. These findings provide a mechanism for the role of TRAP1 in cancer, and suggest that TRAP1 may be a useful target for cancer therapy.

Actin filaments are the major structural component of the cytoskeleton and are involved in a wide range of cellular processes. Actin filaments are also dynamic, and their structure and function are regulated by a variety of proteins. One such protein is cofilin, which is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. Here, we show that cofilin can sever actin filaments, and we propose a mechanism for this process. We show that the severing of actin filaments is enhanced by a mechanical torque, which is generated by the geometry of the filament network. This mechanism is critical for the disassembly of highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in processed foods and is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of people, with a recent arrival of people from Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and our results suggest that the island was settled by multiple independent waves of people. In addition, we found that the island is genetically structured, and that the structure is influenced by the geography of the island. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a significant finding because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not interacting with them in person. This work also suggests that people’s positive emotions are not just a function of in-person interaction, and that observing others’ positive experiences can be a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, as well as for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. They also suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in all cells, and the ribosome is the primary protein-synthesizing machine. The ribosome reads the mRNA sequence and translates it into a protein. In addition to the protein-coding sequence, the mRNA also contains a large number of nonprotein-coding RNA (ncRNA) sequences, including microRNAs, transfer RNA (tRNA) precursors, and small nuclear and small nucleolar RNAs. In this study, we show that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can have a profound effect on the translation of the mRNA. We show that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can have a profound effect on the translation of the mRNA. This study provides a deeper understanding of the role of ncRNAs in protein synthesis and opens the door to a deeper understanding of the role of ncRNAs in protein synthesis and translation. This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a key topic in biology, but the causes of the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals have not been tested quantitatively. We show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and that this drives the evolution of body size in the other mammals that have invaded the water.

The common cold is the most common disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. However, the mechanisms that allow the virus to replicate more efficiently in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature are not well understood. Here, we show that the mouse rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the virus replicates more efficiently at cool temperature in the presence of a functional antiviral response. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to detect the presence of surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This mechanosensing system is important for the pathogen because it promotes long-term attachment to surfaces, which is essential for the survival of the bacterium in the environment and in the host. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the mechanisms by which bacteria can sense and respond to their environment. They also highlight the importance of type IV pili in bacterial pathogenesis. View Full-Text

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. However, the impact of these changes on the quality of surface water is unknown. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels for surface water and sediments. This risk is highest in countries with the least stringent environmental regulations. Our results highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of the virus that causes it. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection and can transmit the virus. Our findings suggest that the virus is circulating in deer, and that the species could act as a reservoir for the virus. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlights the need for a more proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. This paper examines the problems associated with building large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions. The problems are not only the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, and biodiversity, but also the displacement of people, the release of greenhouse gases, the loss of aquatic and terrestrial biodiversity, and the disruption of people’s livelihoods and food systems. The paper also examines the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. However, the earliest pathological changes in AD are not associated with these proteins, but rather with soluble Aβ species, which are produced by neurons and astrocytes. Here, we show that neurons produce a variety of cytokines, which are potent activators of microglial cells, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. Thus, we propose that the soluble Aβ species produced by neurons may be the primary cause of chronic inflammation in AD.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in the history of mankind. However, the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens remains elusive. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the earliest known Hellenistic settlement in the Southern Levant. Our results show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the earliest known chicken husbandry. This finding is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of chicken husbandry and the spread of chickens in the ancient world. It also provides evidence for the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and their gradual integration into the local economy, which was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. This work shows that the folding of a large protein is a complex process with multiple steps, each of which is associated with a distinct structure. The results are consistent with the idea that the folding of proteins is a highly regulated process, and that the regulation is necessary to ensure that the folding of proteins is under the control of the cell.

The presence of dinucleoside tetraphosphates in cells is often taken as evidence for stress, but the cellular response to this condition is not well understood. Here, we show that, in response to stress, the concentration of one of these molecules, Np4, increases, and that this increase is critical for the survival of the cell. We also show that Np4 is the primary substrate for decapping of RNA transcripts in the cell, and that this process is required for the rapid degradation of those transcripts.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore the function of T cells and to decrease the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state with a power-law distribution of activity. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned by strain. We also show that diamond can be transformed to graphite by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the relationship between the bandgap and the electronic structure of diamond. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide. We also demonstrate the potential of this peptide as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately connected to the female reproductive tract. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of sperm is enriched with proteins that are female-derived, suggesting that the female reproductive tract provides a source of proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is essential for blood clotting, but its function is also important for the control of bleeding. The protein is released from the vascular endothelium and binds to platelets, where it acts as a carrier for factor VIII. The binding reaction is triggered by flow, and the binding reaction is important for the control of bleeding. We show that the binding reaction can be switched on by force, and that this switch is important for the control of bleeding.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is intimately involved in human health and disease. The human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on the human body, is a major component of the microbiome, but it has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. We have created such a database, which contains over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with historically high per-genome completeness. We use this database to show that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases, and that the human virome is a major contributor to human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability to measure the aerosol–cloud interaction processes simultaneously. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique provides a unique opportunity to study the aerosol–cloud interaction processes. We demonstrate the capability of this technique by analyzing a case study over Beijing. The results show that the aerosol loading increased the droplet number concentration and decreased the droplet effective radius, which is consistent with the expectation. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for the survival of life on the surface of the Earth. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important for the evolution of life on the surface of the Earth. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion homeostasis. Ion channels are composed of a large number of protein subunits, and each subunit has its own function. The pore gate of an ion channel is the part that controls the passage of ions through the channel. In this study, we found that the pore gate of the K+ channel is not a classic bundle-crossing structure, but instead, it is spatially overlapped with the inactivation gate. This study provides a new perspective for the study of ion channel function. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the host, but the mechanism of invasion is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion, rather than the parasite acting alone. This would have major implications for the development of antimalarial drugs.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic properties can be further improved by tuning the bandgap. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly in a wide range. We also show that the bandgap can be completely closed by strain engineering, which is a unique feature of diamond. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza virus infection and exacerbates disease outcome. Our study provides insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus disease. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with each word being a branch of the tree. However, this description is incomplete. In this study, we show that the brain’s activity during language processing is better described as a series of nested phrases. We also show that the brain’s activity is not only consistent with a tree structure but also provides evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up or left-corner parser to build a hierarchy of nested phrases from the incoming language stream. This parser may be a fundamental component of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates, and its regulation is critical for development and homeostasis. Axin is one of the two major scaffolds in the pathway, and its regulation is critical for the pathway’s function. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level, but differ in their regulation on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to fine-tune the pathway’s function in different tissues.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we present a characterization of the brain circuit that promotes overeating in mice. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice, and that this effect is blocked by dopamine antagonists. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for the development of new therapies for obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the functioning of the global nitrogen cycle. In agriculture, the use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria to supply part of the nitrogen requirements of cereal crops is a major source of nitrogen for plant growth. However, the use of these bacteria is limited by the low efficiency of the process. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the nitrogenase activity of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria is controlled by the presence of the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of nitrogen fixation in the plant-symbiont system. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their senses to explore their environment and interact with their surroundings. In this study, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sound of its prey moving through the air. We demonstrate that the spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and that the spider can localize the direction of the sound source. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing hearing to an external medium, and it provides insights into the evolution of hearing in animals. It also provides a model system for studying the sensing of air flow, which is important for many biological and technological applications. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a major achievement, but the global distribution of vaccines remains a challenge. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This protein can be used to design a VLP vaccine, which may further enhance the immune response. This engineered protein may also be used to design other vaccines, such as subunit vaccines, to improve their manufacturability and immunogenicity.

We report on the identification of a ligand–receptor pair that controls the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the zebrafish homolog of ALKALs, DrALKals. We further show that the DrALKals are required for the development of iridophores, a pigment cell type of neural crest origin. Our results provide evidence for a ligand–receptor pair that is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This finding may have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of neuroblastoma, a cancer that is often associated with mutations in ALK. Our results also provide a tool for studying the function of ALK/LTK family receptors in vivo. View Full-Text

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen in human history is a well-documented event, but the details of its early evolution are still poorly understood. Here, we present the genomes of 17 Yersinia pestis strains from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which spans a period of 10,000 y. Our results show that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage evolving over time. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has released a large amount of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The results of this study highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial forages into annual cropping systems to mitigate climate change. This study also highlights the importance of rotational grazing in maintaining soil health and increasing carbon sequestration. These findings have important implications for the future of agriculture and the global carbon cycle.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 zoonotic viruses, which were all known to be zoonotic. We also developed a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the risk of spillover of any virus. SpillOver is a living database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. In this study, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the red nectar of two distantly related species, which are both visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages. We show that the genetic ancestry of men in the studied population is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestry of women is highly heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. This is the first study to our knowledge that shows that women, rather than men, were the major carriers of the genetic ancestry of the population studied. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides a unique perspective on the demographic processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of strategies to control the spread of this virus. This article

We describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to identify the pathogen landscape in a resource-scarce setting. We show that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify the presence of HIV and malaria in the same patient. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the pathogen landscape and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a model for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings.

The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is synthesized by DNA polymerases in a processive manner. However, the synthesis of DNA on the lagging strand is discontinuous and requires the formation of a complex between the polymerase and the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. This complex is essential for the synthesis of DNA on the lagging strand but is also responsible for the stability of the polymerase. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and found that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable and dissociates rapidly. This finding has profound implications for the synthesis of DNA on the lagging strand as it limits the processivity of the polymerase and promotes the rapid dissociation of the polymerase from the PCNA sliding clamp on DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and the implications for DNA synthesis on the lagging strand. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this study, we describe the construction of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This is a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Finally, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other times. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners alike.

The clinical characteristics of COVID-19 are still unclear, and the treatment is still in the process of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to bind and regulate copper is important for their health and survival. Here we describe the discovery of a fungal natural product that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This discovery expands the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and highlights the importance of studying the role of natural products in the health of fungi. Frost is one of the most important abiotic factors that limit plant growth and survival in the Northern Hemisphere. Despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly linked to the leaf-out timing of trees, and that this relationship is likely to change in the future. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and can inform the development of new insurance policies.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the development of colitis by transitioning to Th1-like cells and that they can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapies. This method will enable the rapid production of large numbers of cells for disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen colonization and disease. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum alters the composition of the gut microbiota to facilitate its colonization of the tick vector. We show that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota and contribute to disease. (Show more)

The study of the evolution of the avian tail is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is because the water vapor in the stratosphere is sensitive to temperature, and the sensitivity of the water vapor to temperature is larger than the sensitivity of temperature to water vapor. This means that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with temperature, and that this increase in water vapor is a feedback to the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and the color of an animal can be used to communicate its identity and behavior. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein binds biliverdin, a molecule that is responsible for the green color of plants. This discovery provides a mechanism for the evolution of color in vertebrates and opens the door to a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

Hypoxia is a key feature of the tumor microenvironment, and is associated with poor prognosis in many cancers. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cells. This study provides a mechanism for the increased frequency of breast cancer cells that are resistant to chemotherapy in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skins in parchment production is not supported by the data.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and processes that led to the extinction and recovery of life on Earth. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is refined to 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, and the timing of the carbon cycle reorganization is refined to 252.25 ± 2.25 and 252.15 ± 2.25 Mya. The results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms and the timing of ecosystem recovery. The results also provide a precise time point for evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and recovery of life on Earth. View Full-Text

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response against the intestinal microbiota. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited by the lack of effective therapeutic strategies. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of IBD. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in the open conformation, which is associated with higher infectivity. Our data suggest that the D614G mutation in the spike protein may increase infectivity by facilitating the binding of the spike to the receptor, ACE2. Our data also suggest that the open conformation of the spike may be a target for the development of neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We also show that the existence of an equilibrium is preserved under small perturbations of the payoffs.
