COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of all chemistry. They are the starting point for the study of chemical reactions, chemical bonding, and the properties of molecules. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this trend is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We believe that this work will be of interest to the chemistry community, as it provides a new way of thinking about the chemical properties of atoms.

We show that changes in human demography can have a large influence on the future fire regime, and that this can have a significant impact on the climate. We find that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity by up to 50%, which can offset warming for up to 10 y at today’s levels. This suggests that fire suppression and ignitions can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. However, we also find that the influence of human demography on fire activity is highly uncertain, and that the influence of climate change on fire activity is also highly uncertain. This highlights the importance of understanding the influence of climate change on fire regimes, and the need to consider the influence of human demography in this context.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a luminescent symbiont in a specific host organ. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the periodic acidification of the host epithelium that is necessary for the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. This study also highlights the importance of the timing of the provision of nutrients in the maintenance of the symbiosis. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. We find that the narratives contain topics that are not captured by the structured variables of the database. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gender bias of the topics is consistent with known patterns in gender biases in semantic space. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, and it can be adapted to new domains. We believe that it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This study shows that the introduction of the plague into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather the result of repeated introductions, each of which was preceded by a climate-driven rodent dispersal. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of introductions of the plague bacterium into Europe, rather than a single introduction.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of marine ecosystems. However, they are also a valuable resource for the seafood industry. In recent years, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. This disease is characterized by rapid death and the loss of the entire body. We show that this disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the virus. This study provides evidence that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we report the results of a preclinical study that shows that antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in treating AML. Our results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also demonstrates the potential of antibody-based therapies for the treatment of AML. Thus, our results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also demonstrates the potential of antibody-based therapies for the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement of the island. The settlement history is also reflected in the distribution of the ancestry across the island, showing that the settlement happened independently from Africa and Asia. This study shows that Madagascar is a unique case, with a unique history, and that the island is not a “natural laboratory” for the study of human evolution. Instead, it is a unique laboratory for the study of the history of Madagascar.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this data to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert assessments to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This has important implications for the management of agricultural production, and for the development of early warning systems for food security.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism can support memory for a range of temporal scales, from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the future of the carbon cycle. In this study, we present the results of the largest global synthesis of soil respiration to date, which provides a comprehensive view of the response of soil respiration to warming across a wide range of biomes. Our results show that soil respiration is not increasing in response to warming in most biomes, and that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration is not increasing with warming. These results suggest that soil respiration may be more resilient to climate change than previously thought, and that the response of soil respiration to climate change may be highly variable across the globe.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most studied, but the molecular mechanisms underlying the process are still poorly understood. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the extent of functional reduction and the establishment of the obligate parasitic lifestyle. They also suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes reach several new rate equilibria during the process of functional reduction. These findings may help us to understand the molecular evolution of plastid genomes and their role in the evolution of life on Earth. View Full-Text

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk is driven by a combination of the changing frequency and intensity of extreme droughts. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional-scale studies to understand the causes of droughts and to quantify the risks of climate change. View Full-Text

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. It demonstrated that quasicrystals are a common and stable state of chemical equilibrium, and that they can be formed by natural processes. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first anthropogenic quasicrystal. This discovery demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed by humans, and that they can be found in the most unexpected places.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth, and the capture of solar energy is the fundamental process by which it occurs. The conversion of light energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the photosynthetic reaction center, which contains the chlorophyll pigments. The synthesis of these pigments is the most productive biological pathway on Earth, and the formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. Here, we describe the evolution of the isocyclic ring, and the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that forms it. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the most productive biological pathway on Earth. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the progression of Alzheimer’s disease. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple signaling pathways, and it is difficult to identify the specific signaling pathway that is responsible for neuroinflammation. In this study, we identified ASK1 as a key signaling pathway that is involved in neuroinflammation. We also identified the specific cell types that are involved in neuroinflammation, which will help us to develop new therapeutic strategies for neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

We find that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in California over the past few decades. This increase is almost entirely due to human activities. The increase in the probability of warm–dry conditions is likely to continue in the future, which will increase the probability of the record-setting droughts that are occurring today.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a promising approach to identify the causal paths that lead to autism. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in its components result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in hematological abnormalities, and show that these mutations cause constitutive activation of the CRAC channel. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of CRAC channel dysregulation, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The study of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is important for understanding the mechanisms of disease and for developing new therapeutic strategies. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain, a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and for developing new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The study of the immune system in bats is important for understanding the evolution of the immune system and the origin of the adaptive immune system in mammals. The study of the immune system in bats is also important for understanding the evolution of the immune system and the origin of the adaptive immune system in mammals.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires one-carbon units for purine and thymidine synthesis. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT), a key enzyme in this process. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a disease in which SHMT inhibition is uniquely effective. Thus, SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer, and particularly for B-cell malignancies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. It also provides a rationale for the use of drugs that target the proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons but not in other tissues. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to have broad impact in the fields of quantum optics, atom optics, and many-body physics.
The study of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the origin of new viral diseases. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes from human remains, which show that parvovirus B19, the virus that causes fifth disease in children and arthritis in adults, has been associated with humans for at least 12.6 thousand years. We also show that the recombination event that formed the human parvovirus B19 genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. These findings provide insights into the evolution of viruses and the origin of human diseases. (Show more)
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern of increasing pain with age is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) continues to cause severe respiratory disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the further development of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a luminescent symbiont in a specific host organ. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the periodic acidification of the host epithelium that is necessary for the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. This study also highlights the importance of the timing of the provision of nutrients in the maintenance of the symbiosis. (Show more)

This paper shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools. This is a significant finding because suspension is a major contributor to the school-to-prison pipeline, which has been shown to have negative consequences for students’ health, well-being, and academic achievement. The paper also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline. This is significant because teachers’ mindsets about discipline are a major contributor to the suspension pipeline. The paper provides evidence that this change can be achieved through a scalable intervention. This is significant because it shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools without relying on punitive measures.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the stalling and mutagenesis of pol II at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites are exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of infection, we engineered MERS-CoV to resist proteolysis during the sequential cleavages that are required for virus binding to cell receptors and for virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that these mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the sequential cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large proportion of obesity and other diet-related diseases. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60% and decrease the proportion of meat meals purchased by 14%. This is a simple and effective way to reduce meat consumption and improve population health and the environment.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with its extracellular environment, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line expressing oncogenes, and show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We also show that the surfaceome is sensitive to the oncogene, and that the glycoproteome is sensitive to the oncogene and the MAPK pathway. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide evidence from the recent expansion of vote-by-mail in the United States. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is unlikely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of viral pathogenesis. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique mechanism of immune evasion.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of endothelin-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. In conclusion

We live in an age of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to make the most of these resources while avoiding the pitfalls of overconfidence. We describe a set of recent developments in selective inference that allow us to make more judicious use of the data and to avoid the pitfalls of overconfidence. We illustrate the use of these methods in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help readers to avoid some of the pitfalls of overconfidence that can arise in the era of big data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a key factor for the induction of ECs. ETV2 is a member of the ETS family of transcription factors, which are known to play important roles in the development of hematopoietic cells. Here, we show that ETV2 is also essential for the induction of ECs. Our study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach can be applied to the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)
We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentor receptors, which are involved in the development of the zebrafish eye and body coloration.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. Here, we identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. We also identified a sequence-dependent network of interactions that favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings provide insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging mechanism and might lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study was to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow and plays a critical role in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity. However, the role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the need for policies to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Finally, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other times. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. View Full-Text

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response in disease progression is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, which allows for the characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual animals. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and that the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the peak viral load and shortening the time to undetectable viral load. Our results provide a framework for the design of future clinical trials and for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are poorly understood, and the consequences of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are poorly documented. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts are a key driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis. We provide evidence that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress is a key driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis, which will lead to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis and the collapse of the coral holobiont. Our findings highlight the importance of the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its symbionts in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of endosymbiotic associations in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the intestinal microbiome, leading to a loss of the intestinal barrier. We also show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn can stimulate tumor growth. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain the integrity of the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in this population. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is a major determinant of the outcome of the disease. In this study, we show that the activation of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is associated with the development of resistance to chemotherapy in breast cancer patients and mice. Furthermore, we show that targeting ROR1 with an anti-ROR1 antibody may improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is a matter of debate. Here, we show that the start of this event is linked to a volcanic eruption series that occurred at the same time as the onset of a period of enhanced stratospheric ozone depletion.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost during development and is not restored after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes and pathways that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of DNA replication. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in all organisms, including humans. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur at the start of genes than in the middle or end of genes. These results provide a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant, which will be useful for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants and for understanding the genetic basis of disease in humans.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the control of cognitive and motor functions. The present study provides a method to identify and validate resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. The results show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this network is subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients. Task-related deactivation of the dominant resting state network was reduced in PD patients, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a method to assess the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of mRNA. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that the NAD+ cap is not a product of RNA processing, but is instead produced cotranscriptionally. This discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast raises the possibility that the NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subsets of mRNAs.

The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes is a relatively new field. We show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. This study also provides a resource of DNA methylation data from blood cells of people with diabetes. These data can be used to study the mechanisms of epigenetic changes in diabetes and to develop new therapeutic strategies.
This study provides evidence that FSIP1 is a potential therapeutic target in TNBC and may aid in the design of therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the changes in the gut barrier. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of fruit aroma, but the biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of other compounds that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit. Our results provide a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be useful for the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional architecture is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons in MEC. These data provide a detailed view of the spatial organization of neurons in MEC and will facilitate future studies of the functional role of this region in navigation. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system in the brain that is critical to dopamine function. We show that striatonigral fibers originate from striosomes, which are specialized subcompartments of the nucleus basalis of Meynert. These striatonigral fibers form bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent cell bodies in the ventral tegmental area. We suggest that these striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for this function and are the only cells in the heart that have the ability to generate action potentials. SAN cells are also responsible for the generation of electrical signals that coordinate the contraction of the heart. The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and opens up a new avenue for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, and it is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, despite the fact that small tributaries are the most common source of nutrients to lakes. We show that small watersheds can be a significant source of coastal nutrients, especially in large lakes. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that efforts to reduce nutrient loading in lakes should focus on these overlooked sources.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to access only a small fraction of the network’s chemical concentrations. We find that the network’s dynamics are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment’s access to the network’s concentrations. We show that this bias can be used to predict the network’s steady-state concentrations, even in the absence of detailed knowledge of the network’s kinetics. We also show that the bias can be used to control the network’s dynamics, and that it can be used to design networks that are more robust to perturbations. Our results suggest that the environment’s access to the network’s concentrations may play a fundamental role in the dynamics of complex chemical systems.

We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, and that these changes can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers insights into the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, which can help in the development of new therapies.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system and its response to external forcing. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in the amount of organic matter entering the ocean and to an increase in the amount of nutrients reaching the surface ocean. These results provide insights into the mechanisms that can lead to abrupt climate change and highlight the importance of organic matter in the Earth system. View Full-Text

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many countries and corporations have made commitments to reduce this impact. Certification is the main tool used to meet these commitments, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that the impact is small and limited to areas that are already degraded. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the sex of an individual can have a profound effect on its fitness. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with four possible sex classes. We find that the interplay of sex determination alleles in M. mbenjii produces modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits, and that the evolution or introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner creates additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results highlight the potential for polygenic sex determination to produce a wide range of sexual phenotypes, and the evolutionary consequences of such variation. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A and can damage the retina. We show that the presence of iron in the retina can promote the oxidation and degradation of these species. This finding has implications for the retina in health and disease.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the loss of morphological and functional optimizations. Here we show that specialization can be maintained and even enhanced by the evolution of morphological innovations, and that specialization can be shifted to other prey types. These findings help understand the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological evolution in the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The study of the hand is complicated by the fact that the hand is the most mobile part of the body and, therefore, the most difficult to preserve. However, the study of the hand is important because it provides insight into the evolution of the human brain and the evolution of intelligence. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit biosynthetic enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that this enzyme is a promising target for cancer therapy, and that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of natural landscapes. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for a more holistic approach to understanding the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, and the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting other sustainable development goals.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but at the same time, it has increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to compaction of the soil. We show that the weight of farm machinery has increased by a factor of 10 since the 1950s, and that the weight of harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
